verses.textEn: Paul, a prisoner of Christ Jesus, and Timothy, a brother, to Philemon, our beloved fellow laborer,
verses.textLa: Paulus vinctus Christi Iesu, et Timotheus frater: Philemoni dilecto, et adiutori nostro,

verses.textEn: and to Apphia, most beloved sister, and to Archippus, our fellow soldier, and to the church which is in your house.
verses.textLa: et Appiæ sorori charissimæ, et Archippo commilitoni nostro, et Ecclesiæ, quæ in domo tua est.

verses.textEn: Grace and peace to you, from God our Father and from the Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: Gratia vobis, et pax a Deo Patre nostro, et Domino Iesu Christo.

verses.textEn: I give thanks to my God, always keeping remembrance of you in my prayers,
verses.textLa: Gratias ago Deo meo, semper memoriam tui faciens in orationibus meis,

verses.textEn: (for I am hearing of your charity and faith, which you have in the Lord Jesus and with all the saints)
verses.textLa: audiens charitatem tuam, et fidem, quam habes in Domino Iesu, et in omnes sanctos:

verses.textEn: so that the participation of your faith may become evident by the recognition of every good work which is in you in Christ Jesus.
verses.textLa: ut communicatio fidei tuæ evidens fiat in agnitione omnis operis boni, quod est in vobis in Christo Iesu.

verses.textEn: For I have found great joy and consolation in your charity, because the hearts of the saints have been refreshed by you, brother.
verses.textLa: Gaudium enim magnum habui, et consolationem in charitate tua: quia viscera sanctorum requieverunt per te, frater.

verses.textEn: Because of this, I have enough confidence in Christ Jesus to command you concerning certain things,
verses.textLa: Propter quod multam fiduciam habens in Christo Iesu imperandi tibi quod ad rem pertinet:

verses.textEn: but I beg you instead, for the sake of charity, since you are so much like Paul: an old man and now also a prisoner of Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: propter charitatem magis obsecro, cum sis talis, ut Paulus senex, nunc autem et vinctus Iesu Christi:

verses.textEn: I beg you, on behalf of my son, whom I have begotten in my chains, Onesimus.
verses.textLa: Obsecro te pro meo filio, quem genui in vinculis, Onesimo,

verses.textEn: In times past, he was useless to you, but now he is useful both to me and to you.
verses.textLa: qui tibi aliquando inutilis fuit, nunc autem et mihi, et tibi utilis,

verses.textEn: So I have sent him back to you. And may you receive him like my own heart.
verses.textLa: quem remisi tibi. Tu autem illum, ut mea viscera, suscipe:

verses.textEn: I myself wanted to retain him with me, so that he might minister to me, on your behalf, while I am in the chains of the Gospel.
verses.textLa: quem ego volueram mecum detinere, ut pro te mihi ministraret in vinculis Evangelii:

verses.textEn: But I was willing to do nothing without your counsel, so as not to make use of your good deed as if out of necessity, but only willingly.
verses.textLa: sine consilio autem tuo nihil volui facere, uti ne velut ex necessitate bonum tuum esset, sed voluntarium.

verses.textEn: So perhaps, then, he departed from you for a time, so that you might receive him again for eternity,
verses.textLa: Forsitan enim ideo discessit ad horam a te, ut æternum illum reciperes:

verses.textEn: no longer as a servant, but, in place of a servant, a most beloved brother, especially to me: but how much more to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord!
verses.textLa: iam non ut servum, sed pro servo charissimum fratrem, maxime mihi: quanto autem magis tibi et in carne, et in Domino?
verses.notes: Onesimus was a slave (or indentured servant) who fled, was converted to Christianity by Paul and others, and who then was sent back to his master. His transition from a slave to a servant is a figure for the transition that a person makes who is freed from the slavery of sin, so as to become the servant of all in Christ Jesus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if you hold me to be a companion, receive him as you would me.
verses.textLa: Si ergo habes me socium, suscipe illum sicut me:

verses.textEn: But if he has harmed you in any way, or if he is in your debt, charge it to me.
verses.textLa: Si autem aliquid nocuit tibi, aut debet: hoc mihi imputa.

verses.textEn: I, Paul, have written this with my own hand: I will repay. And I need not tell you, that you are also in debt yourself, to me.
verses.textLa: Ego Paulus scripsi mea manu: ego reddam, ut non dicam tibi, quod et teipsum mihi debes:

verses.textEn: So it is, brother. May I delight with you in the Lord! Refresh my heart in Christ.
verses.textLa: ita frater. Ego te fruar in Domino: Refice viscera mea in Christo.
verses.notes: The last phrase ‘in Domino’ was changed to ‘in Christo’ in accord with the 1590 Sixtus V edition of the Vulgate.

verses.textEn: I have written to you, trusting in your obedience, knowing, too, that you will do even more than what I say.
verses.textLa: Confidens in obedientia tua scripsi tibi: sciens quoniam et super id, quod dico, facies.

verses.textEn: But also, at once, prepare a lodging for me. For I am hoping, through your prayers, to present myself to you.
verses.textLa: Simul autem et para mihi hospitium: nam spero per orationes vestras donari me vobis.

verses.textEn: Greet Epaphras, my fellow captive in Christ Jesus,
verses.textLa: Salutat te Epaphras concaptivus meus in Christo Iesu,

verses.textEn: and Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my helpers.
verses.textLa: Marcus, Aristarchus, Demas, et Lucas, adiutores mei.

verses.textEn: May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.
verses.textLa: Gratia Domini nostri Iesu Christi cum spiritu vestro. Amen.
